text: hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new album
forceps these guys are a French rock
quartet and even though this is their
debut LP the band members do have ties
to more established groups in France's
hardcore and post hardcore scene like
pigeon and as we draw and birds in row
the last of which actually had a pretty
decent album come out last year however
I wasn't that crazy about the LP there
wasn't much on it melodically or riff
wise this stuck out to me considering
how many bands there are out there right
now combining the ferocity and the speed
of punk music with sludgy metal
production there's a lot of bands on
Southern Lord doing this sound some
recent additions to Death Wish
incorporated like Code Orange kids or
Oathbreaker nails trap them this routine
is hell
Kurt Beaulieu of converge actually
produces quite a few of the group's
going for this sound and I think even a
moderate fan of extreme music will pick
up the converge influence and calve
Ayers music right away along with some
sounds coming from the world's a crust
Punk and D bead and black metal and
grindcore there are some very
complicated grooves that feel almost
math rock inspired on this LP too but I
wouldn't really say that clear
inspiration hurts the enjoyability of
this album in any major way it
definitely doesn't lessen the impact of
the unrelenting tooth clenched anger
disdain on every song now from what I've
read about this LP the band tracked it
live and it definitely sounds like that
a whirlwind of rock instrumentation all
turned up to 11 with gunshot drums and
hellish vocals heavy heavy guitars and
the aggressive parts that are here are
detailed and interesting enough to dive
into not just sort of let them pummel
you to death the opener on here starts
off with some incredibly fast and tense
and off-kilter guitar riffs that are
syncopated very tightly with the drums
and all of this rhythm all of these
riffs they just move so fast it's it's
difficult to describe them as anything
else but kind of a blur guitars pretty
much dominate the entire track with the
exception of
a few moments around the 1-minute mark
where some really gruesome group vocals
sort of overtake them but only for a
little bit and this track segues right
into the next song like they're both the
same song it's just such a fast
transition and on this track pummeling
riffs are accented with really shrill
guitar chords the band starts chugging
through a groove slows down the tempo
progressively gets slower and slower and
slower until they hit this sludgy
depressive stride that kind of sounds
like the harsh come down after the anger
Laden crack they doled out on the first
song the band starts to show off their
instrumental dynamics on the next track
where Asajj it's a 4-minute song one of
the longer tracks on this LP which for
the most part is filled with songs that
barely reach the two-minute mark there's
a very bleak build of guitar leads and
primal drums on this part of the track
and then the song eventually breaks
through into a series of brick to your
face riffs and blast beats so many of
these tracks shift and change so quickly
what they're doing but what it's
changing from is one incredibly intense
moment to another incredibly intense
moment but on the end of this particular
track there is a very beautiful and
dreary set of slower guitar chords that
are played through where the vocals are
actually in the background trying to add
some element of harmony so sometimes the
changes that these songs undergo are
significant but still I do wish that the
vocals stuck out a little bit more and
did bring maybe a bit of a gentle or
vibe at this point in the song I guess
in a sense it just kind of feels a
little OneNote I can also hear the
vocals pushing outside of that screaming
role on the song caret L and this track
has some really slow melodic guitar
passages that make for one of the more
emotionally powerful moments on this
album but still on this track I'm sort
of left wishing that the vocals brought
more of a sea-change the instrumental
dynamics on this LP continue on tracks
like Oh porks the longest track on this
entire LP is six minutes it kicks off
with some marching snare drums and some
very dismal guitar chords this moment in
the song is very thin it's very trebly
but then eventually the bass kicks in
the song gets really thunderous and
unrelenting and the longer it goes the
more the track feels like being tossed
down a bottomless pit and you're
surrounding the slowly grow darker
darker and darker and even though the
slower spots on here the more melodic
spots to me are the ones that truly
stick out there are riffs on this album
that though for the very short amount of
time that they play do feel very catchy
they feel visceral they really whip me
into a friends you've just wanted to bob
my head and wave and fly up my arms of
violently there are some guitar tone
changes here and there as well but for
the most part you're gonna be hearing
the thunderous riffs that you catch
right at the beginning of the album and
again to go back to the one major issue
that this LP has a lot of this LP just
kind of coasts by in a bit of a frenzy
not that this album is forgettable
because you will most definitely not
forget the impact and the aggression
that this band brings to the table but
the details of it do end up being fuzzy
even after multiple listens and it's not
really for lack of tight playing or
fantastic production or great ideas this
LP has that I actually think there are
some better writing ideas on this thing
than there are on some albums that are
similarly frenzied metallic hardcore
fusions the songs on this record aren't
really organized in a very cohesive way
and if one of the goals here is to be as
disorienting as possible mission
accomplished
the music is slightly nihilistic in this
way but it is strangely satisfying
despite it all of this nihilism kind of
comes to a head on the last track where
every single instrument in the mix is
trying to make as much noise as possible
as fast as possible just before the
audio of the song just cuts out into
pure silence which in a nutshell is kind
of this album however for the short
period of time that this LP does last
the noise that it's making is incredibly
intense loud well recorded just there's
an impressive level of energy and
stamina and rhythmic complexity to a lot
of these songs that just keeps me coming
back despite the fact that some things
just aren't sticking I'm feeling a light
7 on this thing transition if you've
given this LP listened what did you
think of it did you love it
hate it why what do you think I should
review next and that's it Anthony Fantan
oh god forever
